docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A July 6 letter on donations in disaster or refugee situations like that in the Balkans notes problems that result from unused pharmaceutical donations.
docs.abstract: Harvard School of Public Health Prof Michael R Reich letter responds to Dr David Brendling-Bennett July 6 letter on donations in refugee situations like that in Balkans; suggests requiring all drug donors to purchase disposal insurance
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    A July 6 letter on donations in disaster or refugee situations like that in the Balkans notes problems that result from unused pharmaceutical donations.

docs.lead_paragraph: The soaring cost of prescription drugs for aging auto workers and retirees is the top health care issue in national labor talks pitting the United Automobile Workers union against General Motors, Ford Motor and DaimlerChrysler A.G., auto executives said. While many industries face rising costs for pharmaceutical benefits, the auto makers said they had particularly acute problems. Benefits consultants, who compare costs in various industries, agree.

headline.main: Auto Industry Focuses Talks On Health Care

docs.abstract: Soaring cost of prescription drugs for aging auto workers and retirees is top health care issue in national labor talks pitting United Auto Workers union against General Motors, Ford Motor and DaimlerChrysler AG; Ford's expense for pharmaceutical benefits, which includes cost of covering retirees and their spouses, is approaching $2,800 annually for each active hourly worker; that is roughly six times typical cost in large companies; auto makers' costs for prescription benefits are also rising 10 percent to 18 percent a year; union opposes broad changes in its members' health plan when current labor contracts with auto makers expires on Sept 14 (M)
docs.snippet: The soaring cost of prescription drugs for aging auto workers and retirees is the top health care issue in national labor talks pitting the United Automobile Workers union against General Motors, Ford Motor and DaimlerChrysler A.G., auto executives...

docs.lead_paragraph: Charles Holmes was sitting in his wheelchair in his double-wide mobile home when he heard the news that somebody up North had run off with the money from a half-dozen Southern insurance companies. ''At first it didn't register,'' Mr. Holmes said. ''Then I said, 'Hey, I got a policy with those folks.' It was kind of a shock. I thought, 'This dude has gone and swindled off all the money and some of us are going to be left out in the cold.' ''

headline.main: Worry Over Insurance Fraud Extends to Grave

docs.abstract: Tens of thousands of insurance policyholders in Mississippi and neighboring states are wondering how badly they are going to be hurt by huge fraud that authorities say was pulled off by Martin R Frankel; several hundred million dollars is missing from insurers controlled by Frankel; George Dale, Insurance Commissioner in Mississippi, whose staff first discovered irregularities at Frankel's companies in state--Franklin Protective Life Insurance Co, Family Guaranty Life Insurance Co and First National Life Insurance Co of America--has some reservations, saying he is '99 percent certain' that policyholders will be made whole; Gordon Rusty Haydel, executive director of Mississippi Life and Health Insurance Guaranty Association, is preparing to put levy on more than 640 life insurers doing business in state to make up losses of Frankel companies, which have beeen seized by regulators; Haydel says as many as 300 policyolders may have died in Mississippi since three companies were seized in early May and stopped paying claims (M)
docs.snippet: Charles Holmes was sitting in his wheelchair in his double-wide mobile home when he heard the news that somebody up North had run off with the money from a half-dozen Southern insurance companies.     ''At first it didn't register,'' Mr. Holmes said....

docs.lead_paragraph: Three years after New York State enacted sweeping laws to combat abuses by managed care companies, a survey of city doctors suggests that many of those abuses not only continue but in many cases have grown worse. The state laws, called the Managed Care Bill of Rights, are similar to protections passed in a few other states, and they resemble a national plan supported by President Clinton to try to level the playing field between customers and insurers.

headline.main: Long Delays by H.M.O.'s Cited in New York Report

docs.lead_paragraph: Monitoring Protein Folds Folding laundry is one of life's miserable chores, but doing it properly is not all that difficult, with a little practice. Folding proteins is one of the biotechnology industry's miserable chores, and it can be very hard.
docs.abstract: Los Alamos researchers develop technique that uses green light emitted by jellyfish's protein to determine if protein has folded properly; folding proteins is difficult chore in biotechnology; leaf muntjac is smallest deer species in world, with adults measuring just 20 inches and weighing about 25 pounds; animals were discovered by Wildlife Conservation Society biologist in mountains of Myanmar (Burma); Cassini spacecraft makes second Venus flyby (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In ''Improving Medicare'' (editorial, June 30), you repeat the unsupported allegation that it is ''essential to future cost containment'' for Medicare beneficiaries to join managed-care plans. The evidence, however, shows that managed care cannot control costs, even with continued Medicare overpayment to health maintenance organizations, according to a recent General Accounting Office study, or by cutting services, dumping Medicare patients from insuffiently profitable areas or placing greater restrictions on patients' choice and doctors' judgment.
docs.abstract: James S Bernstein letter, commenting on June 30 editorial on Medicare cost containment, says only rational way to achieve cost control, quality care and coverage for the uninsured is to cover everyone with national health insurance
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    In ''Improving Medicare'' (editorial, June 30), you repeat the unsupported allegation that it is ''essential to future cost containment'' for Medicare beneficiaries to join managed-care plans. The evidence, however, shows that...

docs.lead_paragraph: To an outsider, the fix Nassau County is in might understandably cause bewilderment. The economy here is booming just as loudly as in New York City, its neighbor to the west, with unemployment at 2.8 percent, 25,000 new jobs cropping up every year, and sales tax receipts growing at better than 3 percent annually. Its population of 1.3 million is one of the wealthiest in the nation, with median household income of more than $73,000. Yet the county government is nearly broke.

headline.main: Nassau's Paradox: Wealthy but Nearly Broke

docs.abstract: News analysis of dire financial straits of Nassau County, New York, at time when local economy is booming and sales tax receipts are increasing every year; Republican County Exec Thomas Gulotta's request to state Legislature for bailout is countered by Democratic charges, backed by Wall Street, that he routinely spends more than county takes in; fellow Republicans also cite Gulotta's failures in negotiating county labor contracts, which had led to binding arbitration and big pay raises; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For the parents of the world's first surviving octuplets, born here in December, the birth was followed by a wealth of gifts, including a 5,300-square-foot home, a tractor trailer loaded with baby furniture and a lifetime supply of diapers. But as the octuplets of Nkem Chukwu and Iyke Louis Udobi captured the public's imagination and donations, another couple in the Houston area were struggling to figure out how they would provide for their less publicized accomplishment: the birth of the first sextuplets in Texas.

headline.main: Overshadowed Texas Sextuplets Are Receiving Belated Help

docs.abstract: Chris Ann and Christopher Collins of Kingwood, Tex, are receiving a few gifts now to help with their sextuplets, five of which survive, but only after members of their church learn about their plight; birth of sextuplets in late 1998 got scant media attention because of the birth of octuplets in Houston in December and birth of septuplets in Iowa in November 1997; companies that once donated baby items to couples with multiple births of at least three are beginning to do less and making policies regarding what they will give; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AT a news conference recently in one of the Capitol's many gilded chambers, Senator Barbara Mikulski, a Maryland Democrat, offered a myriad of reasons why a Democratic proposal to give patients new rights within their health insurance plans made sense. She spoke of longer hospital stays, greater access to specialists, better overall care. But perhaps the most intriguing part of her sales pitch was a less technical one.

headline.main: The Nation: Mother Love; Democrats Try Pitching to Maternal Instincts

docs.abstract: Democratic campaign appeals to women as mothers discussed in light of positions on health care, gun control and others issues of particular interest; photos (M)
docs.snippet: AT a news conference recently in one of the Capitol's many gilded chambers, Senator Barbara Mikulski, a Maryland Democrat, offered a myriad of reasons why a Democratic proposal to give patients new rights within their health insurance plans made...

docs.lead_paragraph: LIKE families trading their current home for a larger or smaller one as their space needs change, companies have been rearranging their corporate houses at an increased rate in the last six months due to mergers, acquisitions or consolidations, brokers say. That has led to more than doubling the amount of sublet space filtering back onto the 11-county northern and central New Jersey office market, which now stands at 4.3 million square feet, according to Grubb & Ellis, a national commercial brokerage. Subleases represent 17.4 percent of the overall available office space in the state today, according to Cushman & Wakefield, another national brokerage.

headline.main: In the Region /New Jersey; Office Space for Sublet Jumps as Companies Revamp

docs.abstract: Corporate relocations in New Jersey in recent months have more than doubled amount of sublet space filtering back onto office market in northern and central New Jersey; photos of two such buildings (M)
docs.snippet: LIKE families trading their current home for a larger or smaller one as their space needs change, companies have been rearranging their corporate houses at an increased rate in the last six months due to mergers, acquisitions or consolidations,...
